annotation.TEXT: Oh hey, this is a thing again. I was actually planning on my next video to be for the Rock Force update that happened a while back, but there's a few things that kind of halted that plan after a while (aside from the fact that I've already done 2 playthroughs of that game, I didn't like how most of my footage for the update came out since it would have resulted in a much longer than usual video).

The speed boost is pretty self-explanatory. The Jet Board on the other hand is pretty much the equivalent to Rush Jet in the standard game. It's also the only one of Zero's abilities that uses up weapon energy (and with that, now is also a good time to note that Zero starts off with an Energy Balancer).

My usual weapon explanations aren't really needed for the most part here. Zero gains new techniques after defeating the Robot Masters, all of which are explained in almost full detail once you get them. If there's anything else to note that's not mentioned during these scenes however, I'll bring it up. For example, the attack extension you get from Tank Man also allows you to break through walls.

Every time Zero attacks, he loses a single point of health. Thankfully, there's no way to self-destruct from this (Zero's health doesn't drain from attacks if you have 1 point of life left). To compensate all this, he gains health back each time his attacks hit something, as demonstrated by his starting weapon. The Z-Knuckle is extremely efficient for both taking down enemies and gaining health back, seeing as it deals multiple hits to everything it touches.

First stop, basic mechanics. Zero controls a bit like Mega Man as far as simple movement goes, though his jump feels a bit lower by comparison. His dash is basically a much faster version of Mega Man's slide, and the speed boost gained from it carries over into jumps (much like in the MMX series).

Just to note: I will be doing Yoku Man's stage during this playthrough, but most of the letters will be collected off-screen (their placements and how you generally obtain them are no different than when you're playing as Mega Man).

By contrast, the Zero mode update for Unlimited turns a longer than usual game into a rather short one (or in the very least, it cuts down a moderate amount of time when compared to a usual playthrough with Mega Man).
